column2: John was owned by one James B. Rodgers, a farmer, and "a most every kind of man," as John expressed himself; in fact John thought that his owner was such a strange, wicked, and cross character that he couldn't tell himself what he was.
column3: john was owned by one james b Rodgers, a farmer, and "a most every kind of man," as john expressed himself; in fact john thought that his owner was such a strange, wicked, and cross character that he couldn't tell himself what he was.

column2: Seeing that slaves were treated no better than dogs and hogs, John thought that he was none too young to be taking steps to get away.
column3: Seeing that slaves were treated no better than dogs and hogs, john thought that he was none too young to be taking steps to get away.

column2: Charles was held by James Rodgers, Sr., under whom he said that he had served nine years with faint prospects of some time becoming free, but when, was doubtful.
column3: Charles was held by james Rodgers senior, under whom he said that he had served nine years with faint prospects of some time becoming free, but when, was doubtful.

column2: ARRIVAL FROM VIRGINIA, 1859.
column3: ARRIVAL FROM VIRGINIA, eighteen fifty nine.

column2: JAMES TAYLOR, ALBERT GROSS, AND JOHN GRINAGE.
column3: james TAYLOR, ALBERT GROSS, AND john GRINAGE.

column2: To see mere lads, not twenty-one years of age, smart enough to outwit the very shrewdest and wisest slave-holders of Virginia was very gratifying.
column3: To see mere lads, not twenty one years of age, smart enough to outwit the very shrewdest and wisest slave holders of Virginia was very gratifying.

column2: The young men composing this arrival were of this keen-sighted order.
column3: The young men composing this arrival were of this keen sighted order.

column2: James was only a little turned of twenty, of a yellow complexion, and intelligent.
column3: james was only a little turned of twenty, of a yellow complexion, and intelligent.

column2: A trader, by the name of George Ailer, professed to own James.
column3: A trader, by the name of George Ailer, professed to own james.

column2: He said that he had been used tolerable well, not so bad as many had been used.
column3: He said that he had been used tolerable well, not so bad as many had been used.

column2: James was learning the carpenter trade; but he was anxious to obtain his freedom, and finding his two companions true on the main question, in conjunction with them he contrived a plan of escape, and 'took out.' His father and mother, Harrison and Jane Taylor, were left at Fredericksburg to mourn the absence of their son.
column3: james was learning the carpenter trade; but he was anxious to obtain his freedom, and finding his two companions true on the main question, in conjunction with them he contrived a plan of escape, and 'took out.' His father and mother, Harrison and Jane Taylor, were left at Fredericksburg to mourn the absence of their son.

column2: Albert was in his twentieth year, the picture of good health, not homely by any means, although not of a fashionable color.
column3: Albert was in his twentieth year, the picture of good health, not homely by any means, although not of a fashionable color.

column2: He was under the patriarchal protection of a man by the name of William Price, who carried on farming in Cecil county, Maryland.
column3: He was under the patriarchal protection of a man by the name of William Price, who carried on farming in Cecil county, Maryland.

column2: Albert testified that he was a bad man.
column3: Albert testified that he was a bad man.

column2: John Grinage was only twenty, a sprightly, active young man, of a brown color.
column3: john Grinage was only twenty, a sprightly, active young man, of a brown color.

column2: He came from Middle Neck, Cecil county, where he had served under William Flintham, a farmer.

column2: JAMES ANDY WILKINS, and wife LUCINDA, with their little boy, CHARLES, CHARLES HENRY GROSS, A WOMAN with her TWO CHILDREN--one in her arms--JOHN BROWN, JOHN ROACH, and wife LAMBY, and HENRY SMALLWOOD.
column3: james ANDY WILKINS, and wife LUCINDA, with their little boy, CHARLES, CHARLES HENRY GROSS, A WOMAN with her TWO CHILDREN-one in her arms-john BROWN, john ROACH, and wife LAMBY, and HENRY SMALLWOOD.

column2: The above-named passengers did not all come from the same place, or exactly at the same time; but for the sake of convenience they are thus embraced under a general head.
column3: The above named passengers did not all come from the same place, or exactly at the same time; but for the sake of convenience they are thus embraced under a general head.

column2: James Andy Wilkins "gave the slip" to a farmer, by the name of George Biddle, who lived one mile from Cecil, Cecil county, Maryland.
column3: james Andy Wilkins "gave the slip" to a farmer, by the name of George Biddle, who lived one mile from Cecil, Cecil county, Maryland.

column2: While he hated Slavery, he took a favorable view of his master in some respects at least, as he said that he was a "moderate man in talk;" but "sly in action." His master provided him with two pairs of pantaloons in the summer, and one in the winter, also a winter jacket, no vest, no cap, or hat.
column3: While he hated Slavery, he took a favorable view of his master in some respects at least, as he said that he was a "moderate man in talk;" but "sly in action." His master provided him with two pairs of pantaloons in the summer, and one in the winter, also a winter jacket, no vest, no cap, or hat.

column2: James thought the sum total for the entire year's clothing would not amount to more than ten dollars.
column3: james thought the sum total for the entire year's clothing would not amount to more than ten dollars.

column2: Sunday clothing he was compelled to procure for himself by working of nights; he made axe handles, mats, etc., of evenings, and caught musk rats on Sunday, and availed himself of their hides to procure means for his most pressing wants.
column3: Sunday clothing he was compelled to procure for himself by working of nights; he made axe handles, mats, etc, of evenings, and caught musk rats on Sunday, and availed himself of their hides to procure means for his most pressing wants.

column2: Besides these liberal privileges his master was in the habit of allowing him two whole days every harvest, and at Christmas from twenty-five cents to as high as three dollars and fifty cents, were lavished upon him.
column3: Besides these liberal privileges his master was in the habit of allowing him two whole days every harvest, and at Christmas from twenty five cents to as high as three dollars and fifty cents, were lavished upon him.

column2: His master was a bachelor, a man of considerable means, and "kept tolerable good company," and only owned two other slaves, Rachel Ann Dumbson and John Price.
column3: His master was a bachelor, a man of considerable means, and "kept tolerable good company," and only owned two other slaves, Rachel Ann Dumbson and john Price.

column2: Lucinda, the companion of James, was twenty-one years of age, good-looking, well-formed and of a brown color.
column3: Lucinda, the companion of james, was twenty one years of age, good looking, well formed and of a brown color.

column2: She spoke of a man named George Ford as her owner.
column3: She spoke of a man named George Ford as her owner.

column2: He, however, was said to be of the "moderate class" of slave-holders; Lucinda being the only slave property he possessed, and she came to him through his wife (who was a Methodist). The master was an outsider, so far as the Church was concerned.
column3: He, however, was said to be of the "moderate class" of slave holders; Lucinda being the only slave property he possessed, and she came to him through his wife (who was a Methodist). The master was an outsider, so far as the Church was concerned.

column2: Once in a great while Lucinda was allowed to go to church, when she could be spared from her daily routine of cooking, washing, etc.
column3: Once in a great while Lucinda was allowed to go to church, when she could be spared from her daily routine of cooking, washing, etc

column2: Twice a week she was permitted the special favor of seeing her husband.
column3: Twice a week she was permitted the special favor of seeing her husband.

column2: These simple privations not being of a grave character, no serious fault was found with them; yet Lucinda was not without a strong ground of complaint.
column3: These simple privations not being of a grave character, no serious fault was found with them; yet Lucinda was not without a strong ground of complaint.

column2: Not long before escaping, she had been threatened with the auction-block; this fate she felt bound to avert, if possible, and the way she aimed to do it was by escaping on the Underground Rail Road.
column3: Not long before escaping, she had been threatened with the auction block; this fate she felt bound to avert, if possible, and the way she aimed to do it was by escaping on the Underground Rail Road.

column2: Charley, a bright little fellow only three years of age, was "contented and happy" enough. Lucinda left her father, Moses Edgar Wright, and two brothers, both slaves.
column3: Charley, a bright little fellow only three years of age, was "contented and happy" enough. Lucinda left her father, Moses Edgar Wright, and two brothers, both slaves.

column2: One belonged to "Francis Crookshanks," and the other to Capt. Jim Mitchell.
column3: One belonged to "Francis Crookshanks," and the other to Capt. Jim Mitchell.

column2: Her mother, who was known by the name of Betsy Wright, escaped when she (Lucinda) was seven years of age.
column3: Her mother, who was known by the name of Betsy Wright, escaped when she (Lucinda) was seven years of age.

column2: Of her whereabouts nothing further had ever been heard.
column3: Of her whereabouts nothing further had ever been heard.

column2: Lucinda entertained strong hopes that she might find her in Canada.
column3: Lucinda entertained strong hopes that she might find her in Canada.

column2: Charles Henry Gross began life in Maryland, and was made to bear the heat and burden of the day in Baltimore, under Henry Slaughter, proprietor of the Ariel Steamer.
column3: Charles Henry Gross began life in Maryland, and was made to bear the heat and burden of the day in Baltimore, under Henry Slaughter, proprietor of the Ariel Steamer.

column2: Owing to hard treatment, Charles was induced to fly to Canada for refuge.
column3: Owing to hard treatment, Charles was induced to fly to Canada for refuge.

column2: A woman with two children, one in her arms, and the other two years of age (names, etc., not recorded), came from the District of Columbia. Mother and children, appealed loudly for sympathy.
column3: A woman with two children, one in her arms, and the other two years of age (names, etc, not recorded), came from the District of Columbia. Mother and children, appealed loudly for sympathy.

column2: John Brown, being at the beck of a man filling the situation of a common clerk (in the shoe store of McGrunders), became dissatisfied.
column3: john Brown, being at the beck of a man filling the situation of a common clerk (in the shoe store of McGrunders), became dissatisfied.

column2: Asking himself what right Benjamin Thorn (his professed master) had to his hire, he was led to see the injustice of his master, and made up his mind, that he would leave by the first train, if he could get a genuine ticket _via_ the Underground Rail Road.
column3: Asking himself what right Benjamin Thorn (his professed master) had to his hire, he was led to see the injustice of his master, and made up his mind, that he would leave by the first train, if he could get a genuine ticket underscore via underscore the Underground Rail Road.

column2: He found an agent and soon had matters all fixed.
column3: He found an agent and soon had matters all fixed.

column2: He left his father, mother and seven sisters and one brother, all slaves.
column3: He left his father, mother and seven sisters and one brother, all slaves.

column2: John was a man small of stature, dark, with homely features, but he was very determined to get away from oppression.
column3: john was a man small of stature, dark, with homely features, but he was very determined to get away from oppression.

column2: John and Lamby Roach had been eating bitter bread under bondage near Seaford.
column3: john and Lamby Roach had been eating bitter bread under bondage near Seaford.

column2: John was the so-called property of Joshua O'Bear, "a fractious, hard-swearing man, and when mad would hit one of his slaves with anything he could get in his hands." John and his companion made the long journey on foot.
column3: john was the so-called property of joshua O'Bear, "a fractious, hard swearing man, and when mad would hit one of his slaves with anything he could get in his hands." john and his companion made the long journey on foot.

column2: The former had been trained to farm labor and the common drudgery of slave life.
column3: The former had been trained to farm labor and the common drudgery of slave life.

column2: Being a man of thirty-three years of age, with more than ordinary abilities, he had given the matter of his bondage considerable thought, and seeing that his master "got worse the older he got," together with the fact, that his wife had recently been sold, he was strongly stirred to make an effort for Canada.
column3: Being a man of thirty three years of age, with more than ordinary abilities, he had given the matter of his bondage considerable thought, and seeing that his master "got worse the older he got," together with the fact, that his wife had recently been sold, he was strongly stirred to make an effort for Canada.

column2: While it was a fact, that his wife had already been sold, as above stated, the change of ownership was not to take place for some months, consequently John "took out in a hurry." His wife was the property of Dr. Shipley, of Seaford, who had occasion to raise some money for which he gave security in the shape of this wife and mother.
column3: While it was a fact, that his wife had already been sold, as above stated, the change of ownership was not to take place for some months, consequently john "took out in a hurry." His wife was the property of dr Shipley, of Seaford, who had occasion to raise some money for which he gave security in the shape of this wife and mother.

column2: Horsey was the name of the gentleman from whom it was said that he obtained the favor; so when the time was up for the payment to be made, the Dr. was not prepared. Horsey, therefore, claimed the collateral (the wife) and thus she had to meet the issue, or make a timely escape to Canada with her husband.
column3: Horsey was the name of the gentleman from whom it was said that he obtained the favor; so when the time was up for the payment to be made, the dr was not prepared. Horsey, therefore, claimed the collateral (the wife) and thus she had to meet the issue, or make a timely escape to Canada with her husband.

column2: No way but walking was open to them.
column3: No way but walking was open to them.

column2: Deciding to come this way, they prosecuted their journey with uncommon perseverance and success.
column3: Deciding to come this way, they prosecuted their journey with uncommon perseverance and success.

column2: Both were comforted by strong faith in God, and believed that He would enable them to hold out on the road until they should reach friends.
column3: Both were comforted by strong faith in God, and believed that He would enable them to hold out on the road until they should reach friends.

column2: Henry Smallwood saw that he was working every day for nothing, and thought that he would do better.
column3: Henry Smallwood saw that he was working every day for nothing, and thought that he would do better.

column2: He described his master (Washington Bonafont) as a sort of a rowdy, who drank pretty hard, leaving a very unfavorable impression on Henry's mind, as he felt almost sure such conduct would lead to a sale at no distant day.
column3: He described his master (Washington Bonafont) as a sort of a rowdy, who drank pretty hard, leaving a very unfavorable impression on Henry's mind, as he felt almost sure such conduct would lead to a sale at no distant day.

column2: So he was cautious enough to "take the hint in time." Henry left in company with nine others; but after being two days on the journey they were routed and separated by their pursuers.
column3: So he was cautious enough to "take the hint in time." Henry left in company with nine others; but after being two days on the journey they were routed and separated by their pursuers.

column2: At this point Henry lost all trace of the rest.
column3: At this point Henry lost all trace of the rest.

column2: He heard afterwards that two of them had been captured, but received no further tidings of the others.
column3: He heard afterwards that two of them had been captured, but received no further tidings of the others.

column2: Henry was a fine representative for Canada; a tall, dark, and manly-looking individual, thirty-six years of age.
column3: Henry was a fine representative for Canada; a tall, dark, and manly looking individual, thirty six years of age.

column2: He left his father and mother behind.
column3: He left his father and mother behind.

column2: ARRIVAL FROM RICHMOND, 1859.
column3: ARRIVAL FROM RICHMOND, eighteen fifty nine.

column2: HENRY JONES AND TURNER FOSTER.
column3: HENRY JONES AND TURNER FOSTER.

column2: Henry was left free by the will of his mistress (Elizabeth Mann), but the heirs were making desperate efforts to overturn this instrument.
column3: Henry was left free by the will of his mistress (Elizabeth Mann), but the heirs were making desperate efforts to overturn this instrument.

column2: Of this, there was so much danger with a Richmond court, that Henry feared that the chances were against him; that the court was not honest enough to do him justice.
column3: Of this, there was so much danger with a Richmond court, that Henry feared that the chances were against him; that the court was not honest enough to do him justice.

column2: Being a man of marked native foresight, he concluded that the less he talked about freedom and the more he acted the sooner he would be out of his difficulties.
column3: Being a man of marked native foresight, he concluded that the less he talked about freedom and the more he acted the sooner he would be out of his difficulties.

column2: He was called upon, however, to settle certain minor matters, before he could see his way clear to move in the direction of Canada; for instance, he had a wife on his mind to dispose of in some way, but how he could not tell.
column3: He was called upon, however, to settle certain minor matters, before he could see his way clear to move in the direction of Canada; for instance, he had a wife on his mind to dispose of in some way, but how he could not tell.

column2: Again, he was not in the secret of the Underground Rail Road movement; he knew that many got off, but how they managed it he was ignorant.
column3: Again, he was not in the secret of the Underground Rail Road movement; he knew that many got off, but how they managed it he was ignorant.

column2: If he could settle these two points satisfactorily, he thought that he would be willing to endure any sacrifice for the sake of his freedom.
column3: If he could settle these two points satisfactorily, he thought that he would be willing to endure any sacrifice for the sake of his freedom.

column2: He found an agent of the Underground Rail Road, and after surmounting various difficulties, this point was settled.
column3: He found an agent of the Underground Rail Road, and after surmounting various difficulties, this point was settled.

column2: As good luck would have it, his wife, who was a free woman, although she heard the secret with great sorrow, had the good sense to regard his step for the best, and thus he was free to contend with all other dangers on the way.
column3: As good luck would have it, his wife, who was a free woman, although she heard the secret with great sorrow, had the good sense to regard his step for the best, and thus he was free to contend with all other dangers on the way.

column2: He encountered the usual suffering, and on his arrival experienced the wonted pleasure.
column3: He encountered the usual suffering, and on his arrival experienced the wonted pleasure.

column2: He was a man of forty-one years of age, spare made, with straight hair, and Indian complexion, with the Indian's aversion to Slavery.
column3: He was a man of forty one years of age, spare made, with straight hair, and Indian complexion, with the Indian's aversion to Slavery.

column2: Turner, who was a fellow-passenger with Henry, arrived also from Richmond.
column3: Turner, who was a fellow passenger with Henry, arrived also from Richmond.

column2: He was about twenty-one, a bright, smart, prepossessing young man.
column3: He was about twenty one, a bright, smart, prepossessing young man.

column2: He fled from A.A.
column3: He fled from a a

column2: Mosen, a lawyer, represented to be one of the first in the city, and a firm believer in Slavery.
column3: Mosen, a lawyer, represented to be one of the first in the city, and a firm believer in Slavery.

column2: Turner differed widely with his master with reference to this question, although, for prudential reasons, he chose not to give his opinion to said Mosen.
column3: Turner differed widely with his master with reference to this question, although, for prudential reasons, he chose not to give his opinion to said Mosen.

column2: ARRIVAL FROM MARYLAND.
column3: ARRIVAL FROM MARYLAND.

column2: TWO YOUNG MOTHERS, EACH WITH BABES IN THEIR ARMS--ANNA ELIZABETH YOUNG AND SARAH JANE BELL--WHIPPED TILL THE BLOOD FLOWED.
column3: TWO YOUNG MOTHERS, EACH WITH BABES IN THEIR ARMS-ANNA ELIZABETH YOUNG AND SARAH JANE BELL-WHIPPED TILL THE BLOOD FLOWED.

column2: The appearance of these young mothers at first produced a sudden degree of pleasure, but their story of suffering quite as suddenly caused the most painful reflections.
column3: The appearance of these young mothers at first produced a sudden degree of pleasure, but their story of suffering quite as suddenly caused the most painful reflections.

column2: It was hardly possible to listen to their tales of outrage and wrong with composure.
column3: It was hardly possible to listen to their tales of outrage and wrong with composure.

column2: Both came from Kent county, Maryland, and reported that they fled from a man by the name of Massey; a man of low stature, light-complexioned, with dark hair, dark eyes, and very quick temper; given to hard swearing as a common practice; also, that the said Massey had a wife, who was a very tall woman, with blue eyes, chestnut-colored hair, and a very bad temper; that, conjointly, Massey and his wife were in the habit of meting out cruel punishment to their slaves, without regard to age or sex, and that they themselves, (Anna Elizabeth and Sarah Jane), had received repeated scourgings at the hands of their master.
column3: Both came from Kent county, Maryland, and reported that they fled from a man by the name of Massey; a man of low stature, light complexioned, with dark hair, dark eyes, and very quick temper; given to hard swearing as a common practice; also, that the said Massey had a wife, who was a very tall woman, with blue eyes, chestnut colored hair, and a very bad temper; that, conjointly, Massey and his wife were in the habit of meting out cruel punishment to their slaves, without regard to age or sex, and that they themselves, (Anna Elizabeth and Sarah Jane), had received repeated scourgings at the hands of their master.

column2: Anna and Sarah were respectively twenty-four and twenty-five years of age; Anna was of a dark chestnut color, while Sarah was two shades lighter; both had good manners, and a fair share of intelligence, which afforded a hopeful future for them in freedom.
column3: Anna and Sarah were respectively twenty four and twenty five years of age; Anna was of a dark chestnut color, while Sarah was two shades lighter; both had good manners, and a fair share of intelligence, which afforded a hopeful future for them in freedom.

column2: Each had a babe in her arms.
column3: Each had a babe in her arms.

column2: Sarah had been a married woman for three years; her child, a boy, was eight months old, and was named Garrett Bell.
column3: Sarah had been a married woman for three years; her child, a boy, was eight months old, and was named Garrett Bell.

column2: Elizabeth's child was a girl, nineteen months old, and named Sarah Catharine Young.
column3: Elizabeth's child was a girl, nineteen months old, and named Sarah Catharine Young.

column2: Elizabeth had never been married.
column3: Elizabeth had never been married.

column2: They had lived with Massey five years up to the last March prior to their escape, having been bought out of the Baltimore slave-pen, with the understanding that they were to be free at the expiration of five years' service under him.
column3: They had lived with Massey five years up to the last March prior to their escape, having been bought out of the Baltimore slave pen, with the understanding that they were to be free at the expiration of five years' service under him.

column2: The five years had more than expired, but no hope or sign of freedom appeared.
column3: The five years had more than expired, but no hope or sign of freedom appeared.

column2: On the other hand, Massey was talking loudly of selling them again.
column3: On the other hand, Massey was talking loudly of selling them again.

column2: Threats and fears were so horrifying to them, that they could not stand it; this was what prompted them to flee.
column3: Threats and fears were so horrifying to them, that they could not stand it; this was what prompted them to flee.

column2: As often as six or seven times, said Elizabeth, "I have been whipped by master, once with the carriage whip, and at other times with a raw hide trace.
column3: As often as six or seven times, said Elizabeth, "I have been whipped by master, once with the carriage whip, and at other times with a raw hide trace.

column2: The last flogging I received from him, was about four weeks before last Christmas; he then tied me up to a locust tree standing before the door, and whipped me to his satisfaction."
column3: The last flogging I received from him, was about four weeks before last Christmas; he then tied me up to a locust tree standing before the door, and whipped me to his satisfaction."

column2: Sarah had fared no better than Elizabeth, according to her testimony. "Three times," said she, "I have been tied up; the last time was in planting corn-time, this year.
column3: Sarah had fared no better than Elizabeth, according to her testimony. "Three times," said she, "I have been tied up; the last time was in planting corn time, this year.

column2: My clothing was all stripped off above my waist, and then he whipped me till the blood ran down to my heels." Her back was lacerated all over.
column3: My clothing was all stripped off above my waist, and then he whipped me till the blood ran down to my heels." Her back was lacerated all over.

column2: She had been ploughing with two horses, and unfortunately had lost a hook out of her plough; this, she declared was the head and front of her offending, nothing more.
column3: She had been ploughing with two horses, and unfortunately had lost a hook out of her plough; this, she declared was the head and front of her offending, nothing more.

column2: Thus, after all their suffering, utterly penniless, they reached the Committee, and were in every respect, in a situation to call for the deepest commiseration. They were helped and were thankful.
column3: Thus, after all their suffering, utterly penniless, they reached the Committee, and were in every respect, in a situation to call for the deepest commiseration. They were helped and were thankful.
